text: today on x cast president obama presents
his deficit reduction plan vowing to
veto any plan that doesn't raise taxes
on the rich this is not class warfare
it's math violence in yemen's capital
continues into its second day the worst
since pro-democracy protests began in
the spring and world leaders convene in
New York for the United Nations General
Assembly we can't just cut our way out
of this hole it's going to take a
balanced approach President Obama
unveiled the details of his long-term
deficit reduction package in the Rose
Garden this morning he's looking to save
three trillion dollars over ten years
through a mix of some spending cuts but
significant changes to the tax code
including allowing bush-era tax cuts to
expire and eliminating tax breaks and
loopholes particularly for higher-income
people and corporations he's portraying
this as a simple question of math you
need to make these changes to the tax
code in order to arrive at this larger
number and it sets up a showdown with
Republicans in the House who said
they'll oppose anything that resembles a
tax increase and I will veto any bill
that changes benefits for those who rely
on Medicare but does not raise serious
revenues by asking the wealthiest
Americans or biggest corporations to pay
their fair share the Republicans have
been quick to criticize the president's
proposals House Speaker John Boehner
issued a statement very quickly after
the president spoke saying that pitting
Americans against each other is never a
good idea Republicans have been quick to
portray the president's plan as a form
of class warfare something he rejects
but we can see battle lines being set
and really it's a battle that's likely
to carry all the way into the 2012
election as president obama presents one
vision for the role of government in
society and republicans present a
radically different one he seems ready
for this battle and less interested in
compromise than he was during the summer
when he kept talking about hoping to
reach a
and bargain with Republicans a process
that fell apart finally on the familiar
issue of tax increases government
security forces in yemen's capital
killed 20 pro-democracy protesters
Monday in a second day of violence this
is Laura casanov for the New York Times
in Sanaa Yemen the yemeni capital
witnessed the worst violence that it's
seen against protesters since March the
reason why there hasn't been a lot of
violence against protesters in sanaa for
all of these months while they have been
on the streets is because they only
stayed within their sit-in area but what
happened on sunday is that the
protesters marched outside of their
sit-in area and as soon as they left the
protected sidon area that is guarded by
defected soldiers they came under attack
they came under attack from snipers they
came under attack by security forces who
open fired on them at least some of whom
were using high caliber machine guns and
heavy weaponry well the attack on the
protesters then ignited further war
between Yemen's divided military the
interesting thing about the conflict on
Sunday and now today on monday is that
it came at a time when there were
negotiations going on between leaders
from the opposition and leaders from the
ruling party to possibly sign a transfer
of power deal and what their speculation
about is that perhaps the violence was
intentional to sort of the rails that
political agreement from either side and
world leaders convene in New York as the
United Nations General Assembly opens
its annual meeting the first two days of
the annual gathering of world leaders is
usually kind of a soft opening to the
general debate and in these couple days
they're talking about some broad issues
like a global effort to fight
non-communicable diseases but most of
the activity is sort of frenetically
going on behind closed doors is focused
on the question of the Palestinians
asking for membership in the United
Nations this friday prayers
Mahmoud Abbas is supposed to make a
speech to the General Assembly and then
present a formal request of the Security
Council President Abbas arrived last
night this morning he had his first
meeting with Ban ki-moon during which he
announced his intention to go ahead with
a request of the Security Council that
of course has the United States the
European Union Russia and the United
Nations who are trying to come up with
the sort of negotiating plan for the
Palestinians they are all scrambling to
try and make sure that comes together
before friday the Middle East has long
been a focus of the United Nations and
its 66-year history the fight between
the Israeli Palestinians goes back to
them and this year again it's giving
some sense of excitement to the General
Assembly because its first time in many
years that it's had a focus even if it's
an old focus
